title.native: ヘイロー・レジェンズ

description:
This sweeping science-fiction saga delves into the rich Halo universe with 7 exciting stories including tales of Master Chief's mysterious origins, the Spartans' advanced combat capabilities and the tense rivalry between Spartans and Orbital Drop Shock Troopers (ODSTs).

(Source: Warnervideo.com)

1) Origins Part1 (STUDIO 4℃)
2) Origins Part2 (STUDIO 4℃)
3) The Duel (Production I.G)
4) Homecoming (Production I.G/BEETRAIN)
5) Odd One Out (Toei Animation)
6) Prototype (Bones)
7) The Babysitter (STUDIO 4℃)
8) The Package (Shinji Aramaki)

Note: Since The Package aired in two parts on Halo Waypoint and Origins has two parts the total number of episodes is 9 for the 7 stories. 5 of the 9 episodes aired online, making Halo Legends technically an ONA.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Anthology
tags.description: A collection of separate works collated into a single release.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Artificial Intelligence
tags.description: Intelligent non-organic machines that work and react similarly to humans.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Religion
tags.description: Centers on the belief that humanity is related to supernatural, transcendental, and spiritual elements.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Clone
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is an artificial exact copy of another organism.

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/oshii_mamoru)

An anime and live-action director, mostly known for the former, whose seminal titles include [Urusei Yatsura 2: Beautiful Dreamer](https://anilist.co/anime/1921/), [Angel's Egg](https://anilist.co/anime/885/), the first two [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/1095/) films and the [Ghost in the Shell](https://anilist.co/anime/43/) films, as well as the Kerberos Saga universe of which [Jin-Roh](https://anilist.co/anime/570/) is a part.

His affinity for Euro arthouse cinema, his falling out with the Christian religion, and his fascination with the unsuccessful anti-occupation, pro-communist protest movement in postwar Japan shaped his unusual sensibilities. Recurring themes and aesthetics in his works include oppressive police states, unsuccessful protest movements, dysfunctional bureaucracies, political action that results in stasis, biblical scripture, and imagery, philosophical dilemmas, characters trapped in seemingly inescapable situations, the use of dialog as descriptive "texture" rather than a plot-driver, and otherwise Euro-arthouse pacing and storyboarding. He is both polarizing to mainstream audiences, and highly revered by cinephiles and Hollywood directors; his works have influenced Hollywood films such as Dark City, The Matrix, and Avatar.

[Kenji Kamiyama](https://anilist.co/staff/100348/), an anime director also closely associated with [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/), is his protégé.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kawasak54965532)

Hiroyuki Kawasaki is a screenwriter and novelist.

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/tomoki_kyoda/)

Influenced by Hiroyuki Nakano's commercials and music videos, he studied video art at the Musashino Art University, joining Gento Matsumoto's company Sal Brunei as a graphic designer. He soon changed his occupation to the animation industry, having aspired to be an animation director since his childhood. 

He initially joined [Group TAC](https://anilist.co/studio/86/Group-TAC) where he worked as episode director and storyboard artist under the guidance of [Mitsuru Hongou](https://anilist.co/staff/103366/Mitsuru-Hongou). His first major role was as mechanical/creature designer on [Chikyuu Bouei Kazoku](https://anilist.co/anime/1962/The-Daichis--Earths-Defense-Family/), working alongside [Shouji Kawamori](https://anilist.co/staff/97501/Shouji-Kawamori) and [Kazutaka Miyatake](https://anilist.co/staff/100987/Kazutaka-Miyatake), with whom he would collaborate profusely afterwards. 

He later moved to studio [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/bones) landing as assistant director for [Yutaka Izubuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/99075/Yutaka-Izubuchi)'s [RahXephon](https://anilist.co/anime/165/RahXephon/). The two became close collaborators, with Kyouda soon taking the leading role on the [RahXephon: Pluralitas Concentio](https://anilist.co/anime/758/RahXephon-The-Motion-Picture/) movie.

Soon after, he directed [Eureka Seven](https://anilist.co/anime/237/Eureka-Seven/), incorporating his love for music and different sub-cultures into mecha anime.

__Graduated:__ Toyo University

During school Sawai always aimed to be manga artist. After graduating from Toyo University he joined Tatsunoko Production where he became a storyboard artist and later episode director. He served two more years as a production assistant there until he left and became a freelance episode director. Today he works mainly for Bee Train, whose founder Kouichi Mashimo is a good friend of his.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/石川光久)

Co-founder and representative director of [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/). The studio is named after him and [Takayuki Gotou](https://anilist.co/staff/103266/).

Ishikawa acted as executive producer for the anime sequence The Origin of Ren in Kill Bill, and was the producer of the first two [Ghost in the Shell](https://anilist.co/anime/43/) films. In 2005, Ishikawa joined his first joint Japanese-U.S. collaboration, since the opening of the Production I.G branch in Los Angeles, IGPX: Immortal Grand Prix, a joint production with Production I.G and Cartoon Network. Ishikawa has also produced Batman: Gotham Knight, Halo Legends and Dante's Inferno: An Animated Epic.

He also served as an executive at Bee Train from 1997 to 2006.

(Source: Wikipedia)

The president of Studio 4°C, an animation studio she founded with Koji Morimoto and Yoshiharu Sato in 1986. Tanaka is also the chief executive officer of a production company called Beyond C, which initiated the project with Michael Arias that became Tekkon Kinkreet. 

Tanaka was an executive producer on Tekkon Kinkreet and Mind Game, both Studio 4°C films. She was also an animation producer on Beyond and The Second Renaissance Part 1 for the Animatrix project. Tanaka previously worked with Studio Ghibli and played the role of line producer on My Neighbor Totoro and Kiki's Delivery Service.
**Toshiyuki Kanno** is a Japanese character designer, animator, animation supervisor and animation director, affiliated with Studio Live.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/二村秀樹)

Affiliated with [Studio 4°C](https://anilist.co/studio/13/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%9D%91%E6%9C%A8%E9%9D%96)

Yasushi Muraki is an animator and an occasional director affiliated with [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).

Admired [Ichirou Itano](https://anilist.co/staff/103268/) and [Masami Oobari](https://anilist.co/staff/100660/), and became an animator. He is skilled in mechanical and action animation, and is one of three animators alongside [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/) and [Masami Gotou](https://anilist.co/staff/129865/) who are said to have fully mastered the "Itano Circus" drawing technique. He was invited to join the production of [Eureka Seven](https://anilist.co/anime/237/) by [Kenichi Yoshida](https://anilist.co/staff/103498/), who was in charge of character designs and became the special effects director of the series, fully demonstrating his skills.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/snjaramaki) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/荒牧伸志) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shinji_Aramaki)

Aramaki is one of the leading figures in the industry's CG animation, and is noted for his various design works in numerous anime series such as [Gasaraki](https://anilist.co/anime/782/), [Witch Hunter Robin](https://anilist.co/anime/7/), [Wolf's Rain](https://anilist.co/anime/202/) and [Soul Eater](https://anilist.co/anime/3588/) among many others.

Influenced by [Space Battleship Yamato](https://anilist.co/anime/1650/), [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/), and Star Wars during his junior and senior high school years, he decided to pursue a career in film. One of his first representative works was an independently produced animation titled "Moonstruck Artemis," that he made while part of a manga club during his university days. Aramaki didn't have a special desire to work in the animation industry, but has stated joining it solely because he could draw and the industry had a wide range of options for someone like that. He has also said that the spread of digital technology has made it easier for him to work in both anime and live-action.

In 2004, Aramaki directed [Appleseed](https://anilist.co/anime/54/), a re-interpretation of a [Shirou Masamune](https://anilist.co/staff/97609/) manga by [the same name](https://anilist.co/manga/30668/). Although bashed by critics, the movie was an influential piece in the medium that had great impact on creators around the world. Studio Ghibli co-founder [Toshio Suzuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101638/) said the movie would reform the industry.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/中鶴勝祥)

Originating from [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/). Most known for his work in the [Digimon](https://anilist.co/anime/552/) franchise.
**Toshiyuki Kanno** is a Japanese character designer, animator, animation supervisor and animation director, affiliated with Studio Live.
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/manamu_n)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/二村秀樹)

Affiliated with [Studio 4°C](https://anilist.co/studio/13/).
Originating from [Tezuka Productions](https://anilist.co/studio/200/), currently affiliated with [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).

Started his career as an in-betweener for [Nakamura Production](https://anilist.co/studio/6658/Nakamura-Production) working on several outsourced episodes of [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/Sunrise) shows. 

He had his breakthrough as animator on [Yoroiden Samurai Troopers](https://anilist.co/anime/1264/) where his detailed art and animation attracted attention. He was thus selected to be character designer for the sequel, [Yoroiden Samurai Troopers Gaiden](https://anilist.co/anime/1265/), and later animation director for the [Mobile Suit Gundam F91](https://anilist.co/anime/88/) movie. 

Since then he's been heavily involved in Sunrise productions, both as animator and as character designer. Notable examples of his designs are those for [Mobile Suit Gundam Wing](https://anilist.co/anime/90/) and [Argento Soma](https://anilist.co/anime/285/).

He had his debut as a director with [Witch Hunter Robin](https://anilist.co/anime/7/), after which he directed the acclaimed [Ergo Proxy](https://anilist.co/anime/790/). More recent works of his include the adaptation of [Gangsta](https://anilist.co/anime/20773/), as well as the [Mobile Suit Gundam Hathaway](https://anilist.co/anime/105595/) trilogy.

__Notable works outside Anime:__

- Final Fantasy IX (Video Game, 2000) (Character Design)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/佐藤大)
Originating from [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/)'s finishing department.
*Not to be confused with the CG Artist [Kouji Yamazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/337060)*

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/n_nagakawa)

**Date of Birth:** 1974

Naruki Nakagawa is a japanese screenwriter and manga author.
